inspected-cases.notes: ORDER_OF_ASSERTIONS

notes: While method-a and method-b are stateful because they can both throw exceptions, method-a simply returns the field variable DefaultExecuteResultHandler.exitValue, and method-b simply returns the field variable DefaultExecuteResultHandler.exception. Since these two field variables are not related, this is a spurious spec. UNRELATED_STATEFUL_METHODS.

inspected-cases.notes: ORDER_OF_ASSERTIONS - if DefaultExecutorTest.java:227 was moved past DefaultExecutorTest.java:228, then this would have resulted in a stage-1 instead of a stage-0.

validating-test-file: org.apache.commons.exec.DefaultExecutorTest#testExecuteAsyncWithTimelyUserTermination with DefaultExecutorTest.java:228 manually moved to before DefaultExecutorTest.java:224 will show the connection between method-a and method-b.
notes: method-b throws an exception if DefaultExecuteResultHandler.hasResult (a variable signaling that the process is finished and has results) was false; method-a waits on the process until it has a result. One might not always need to call method-a before method-b (in the cases that you didn't need to wait for the process to finish), but in the general case it seems like one ought to call method-a before method-b. DECISION: I'm leaning towards this being a CONNECTION_DOES_NOT_NECESSITATE_ORDERING case, given that method-b will only throw an exception if DefaultExecuteResultHandler.hasResult is not set to true. method-a by itself does not set this field variable, but it waits until the thread running the process has set DefaultExecuteResultHandler.hasResult. Given that the real true spec here is between the asychronous setting of DefaultExecuteResultHandler.hasResult and method-b, with method-a a device to make the parent process wait until the asychronous setting of DefaultExecuteResultHandler.hasResult happens, I don't think there's a true spec relationship between method-a and method-b.

inspected-cases.notes: The assertion fails because DefaultExecuteResultHandler.hasResult() returns false, because method-a was not called (the test didn't wait until the process finished), before method-b was even called. ORDER_OF_ASSERTIONS - if DefaultExecutorTest.java:199 was moved past DefaultExecutorTest.java:200, then the DSI experiment would have resulted in stage-1 instead of stage-0.

validating-test-file: One can call method-b at any point; for example, one can include a call to method-b at around DefaultExecutorTest.java:196 with some int value as the argument, which is before the call to method-a
notes: method-a creates a new thread that runs an internal process, and the return value of method-a is set to the field variable DefaultExecutor.executorThread. method-b performs some checks on the field variable DefaultExecutor.exitValues, which only get populated after method-a is called and the process finishes (if it fails/isn't populated, method-b would return false). So it doesn't really make sense to call method-b before method-a, but I'm not sure to what extent this is a true spec? (This could be "a*b".) DECISION: This spec is most likely a spurious spec because method-b is a public method that can be called at any point, and while method-a is protected, it can also be called at any point. Since neither of the methods by themselves affect the other, this is most likely a UNRELATED_STATEFUL_METHODS case.

notes: method-a creates and runs a new thread that runs the specified internal process. method-b performs some checks on the field variable DefaultExecutor.exitValues, which only get populated after method-a is called and the process finishes (if it fails/isn't populated, method-b would read from its argument, which can only be provided after the process has finished). So it seems like method-a needs to terminate before method-b can be called.. DECISION: This is a spurious-spec because method-b is a public method that can be called at any point. I think the use case makes this a CONNECTION_DOES_NOT_NECESSITATE_ORDERING case.

validating-test-file: Technically method-b can be called at any point; for example, one can call method-b immediately after DefaultExecutorTest.java:178 with some int argument, before method-a is called.
notes: ONE_STATELESS_METHOD. The use case is such that DefaultExecutor.java:222 creates a new Thread that runs the process and assigns it to the field variable DefaultExecutor.executorThread, and method-a is called to retrieve the field variable DefaultExecutor.executhorThread. After the thread has executed and terminated, method-b is called to check whether the process failed or not by either referring to the field variable DefaultExecutor.exitValues or its argument (which is the exit code from the process after DefaultExecutor.executeInternal() runs the process and retrieves the value). So in some very loose sense, you do have to call method-a before method-b, but I don't think the relationship is strictly between these two methods, and strong enough, such that there is a true spec relationship between the two methods. DECISION: This spec is most likely a spurious spec because method-b is a public method that can be called at any point, and while method-a is protected, it can also be called at any point. Since neither of the methods by themselves affect the other, this is most likely a UNRELATED_STATEFUL_METHODS case.

validating-test-file: org.apache.commons.exec.DefaultExecutorTest#testExecute (the reason why this spec's result is stage-0 is because there's a lot of operations from the return value of method-a; but they're also necessary in order for the correctness of the program)
notes: method-a creates and returns a new Process that runs a specified command, and method-b closes all of the streams for the provided Process. The use case in this test/code is that the return value of method-a is being passed into method-b as an argument; hence, one would have to call method-a to call method-b in the first place. Of course, one can pass in an arbitrary Process object to method-b as well, but that would defeat the point of calling method-b. This could be a larger spec with some other operations that potentially depend on method-a?
findings: Type-f: method-b is always immediately preceded by method-a?

validating-test-file: org.apache.commons.exec.DefaultExecutorTest#testExecute (the reason why this spec's result is stage-0 is because there's a lot of operations from the return value of method-a; but they're also necessary in order for the correctness of the program)
notes: ONE_STATELESS_METHOD: method-b is a 1-line naive getter for the field variable DefaultExecutor.exceptionCaught. method-a creates, runs, and returns a new Process that runs a specified command. The field variable DefaultExecutor.exceptionCaught could be modified during the execution of the caller of method-a and method-b, but only if method-a was called first (otherwise, there would be a NullPointerException like the DSI experiment). So, it seems like method-b's return value is dependent on the fact that method-a is executed and returns a valid Process object. This could be a larger spec with some other operations that potentially depend on method-a?
findings: Type-c: method-b is always preceded by method-a

Either variable that is used depends on the fact that the process to terminate/be killed. So, it seems like method-b's return value is dependent on the fact that method-a is executed and returns a valid Process object. notes: method-a performs a synchronous execution of a subprocess running the intended script, and method-b checks the exit value of the subprocess to check whether it failed, and that exit value is the return value of method-a. If one wants to check the result of a synchronous execution, then they must call method-a before method-b, so I think this is a true spec? CHECKS_MISDIRECTED_OUTPUT. DECISION: This is a spurious spec because method-b is a public method that can be called at any point; the common use case being that the return value of method-a gets passed into method-b implies that this is a CONNECTION_DOES_NOT_NECESSITATE_ORDERING case.

inspected-cases.notes: The assertion fails on DefaultExecutorTest.java:524 where the size of exec.getProcessDestroyer() (the field variable DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer) is checked. The subprocess only gets added to the data structure DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer when the process is run within the call to method-a, so the delay to method-a causes DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer to only have size 0, instead of the size 1 that the test was expecting.

The assertion fails on DefaultExecutorTest.java:524 where the size of exec.getProcessDestroyer() (the field variable DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer) is checked. The subprocess only gets added to the data structure DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer when the process is run within the call to method-a, so the delay to method-a causes DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer to only have size 0, instead of the size 1 that the test was expecting.

The assertion fails on DefaultExecutorTest.java:524 where the size of exec.getProcessDestroyer() (the field variable DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer) is checked. The subprocess only gets added to the data structure DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer when the process is run within the call to method-a, so the delay to method-a causes DefaultExecutor.processDestroyer to only have size 0, instead of the size 1 that the test was expecting.

inspected-cases.notes: The assertion on DefaultExecutorTest.java:181 fails because the test expected for the handler to have a result (i.e. the subprocess finished/was terminated). However, since that assertion was between the call to method-a and the call to method-b, there was no result at that point because method-a was not called by that point and therefore the process never started. ORDER_OF_ASSERTIONS - moving DefaultExecutorTest.java:181-182 past DefaultExecutorTest.java:183 may have prevented the DSI experiment from failing at stage-0.

validating-test-file: org.apache.commons.exec.DefaultExecutorTest#testExecuteAsync with method-b called with some int argument between DefaultExecutorTest.java:178 and DefaultExecutorTest.java:179.
notes: method-a performs an asynchronous execution of a subprocess running the intended script, and method-b checks the exit value of the subprocess to check whether it failed, and that exit value is only fetched by DefaultExecuteResultHandler.getExitValue() only if the process initiated by method-a has terminated at that point. This might be more of a spec between method-a and DefaultExecuteResultHandler.getExitValue() rather than between method-a and method-b, but one must start the execution of the subprocess before checking the results of said subprocess. DECISION: method-a and method-b are both from a public interface, and they can technically be called at any point (neither inhibits the other from executing correctly). Note that this could be a SPECIAL_NBP given that the only implementation of method-b is indirectly called via the only implementation of method-a through an asynchronous thread.

inspected-cases.notes: The test crashes because method-a was supposed to set what it expects the process's exit value to be as valid, but since method-a was delayed and not called, DefaultExecutor.executeInternal() took the exit value as invalid and threw an exception instead.

The test fails because method-a was not called before the Executor.execute() call, which prevents the OutputStream variable baos from receiving any output from the subprocess. This causes the check at DefaultExecutorTest.java:105 to fail. ORDER_OF_ASSERTIONS - moving DefaultExecutorTest.java:105-106 past DefaultExecutorTest.java:107 may have prevented the DSI experiment from failing at stage-0.

notes: The only implementation of method-a modifies the field variable DefaultExecutor.streamHandler, and the only implementation of method-b is a 1-line naive getter to the field variable DefaultExecutor.workingDirectory (ONE_STATELESS_METHOD). Since these variables are not related to each other, this is a spurious spec. CHECKS_MISDIRECTED_OUTPUT

In general terms, method-a creates and launches a new process for the given command, and method-b checks whether the exit value of the process signals a failure. It seems like one would have to successfully start the command in order to check its exit value, so I think this is a true spec? Note that DefaultExecutor.executeInternal() manages the calls to method-a and method-b, and that method-b may not necessarily be called (if the user adds values to the field variable DefaultExecutor.exitValues to add in exit values that are valid). DECISION: This is a spurious spec because method-a and method-b are both public methods that can be called at any point. While a common use case is similar to the one in the test, method-b can be called before method-a safely, and vice versa. Given their definitions, it seems like this is a case of UNRELATED_STATELESS_METHODS.

inspected-cases.notes: Since method-a was delayed, the size of processDestroyer ended up staying at 0; so, the assertion that checked whether processDestroyer was empty at the end of the process execution passed.

notes: Note that this is a nbp only when the ProcessDestroyer object is a ShutdownHookProcessDestroyer object (ShutdownHookProcessDestroyer is the only class implementing ProcessDestroyer in the project).

inspected-cases.notes: Since method-a was delayed, the size of processDestroyer ended up staying at 0; so, the assertion that checked whether processDestroyer was empty at the end of the process execution passed. This is also why method-b was never called; the boolean processRemoved at ShutdownHookProcessDestroyer.java:133 was false because there was no Process in processDestroyer to be removed. This causes the if conditional on method-b to evaluate to false. REPLACEMENT_TRIGGERS_CHECK_THAT_PREVENTS_B

notes: The callee of the only implementation of method-a (ShutdownHookProcessDestroyer.addShutdownHook()) registers the ProcessDestroyer object as a shutdown hook, and method-b removes the ProcessDestroyer as a shutdown hook. If method-a is not called before method-b, then method-b becomes a sort of no-op. Note that if there were other implementations of ProcessDestroyer, this may not be a true spec.
findings: Type-b: method-a is never followed by method-b?

inspected-cases.notes: Since method-a was never called, the size of processDestroyer remained at 1 (because ProcessDestroyer.add() added the running process to processDestroyer, and method-a was supposed to clean up that state). The assertion checked whether processDestroyer was empty, and failed.

notes: Note that this is a nbp only when the ProcessDestroyer object is a ShutdownHookProcessDestroyer object (ShutdownHookProcessDestroyer is the only class implementing ProcessDestroyer in the project).

inspected-cases.notes: The test failed because method-a wasn't called, meaning that the process wasn't killed on timeout; this caused the process to exit with a exit value of 0 (because it was able to run to completion), which caused DefaultExecutor.executeInternal() to not throw an exception. This causes the assertion on Exec34Test.java:86 to fail.

notes: Note that this will only be a nbp if the TimeoutObserver instance is also a ExecuteWatchdog instance (currently ExecuteWatchdog is the only subclass of TimeoutObserver).
